list.text:
3D Truss Solver -

Analyze forces and deformation of truss structures under its own weight.

I was largely inspired by a magnetic stick toy I enjoyed in childhood, where I used magnetic sticks and steel beads to build structures that resemble trusses in civil engineering.

In university, I learned computational methods to analyze truss structures. This graph solves for deformation and forces in 3D truss structures using the stiffness method with a conjugate gradient solver.

Modeling of a truss -

A truss in civil engineering is beams (known as members) connected to nodes. Civil engineers typically mathematically analyze them to determine if they are safe.

In this simplified version, each node and member has a downward force caused by gravity. Each member holds a force between connected nodes (positive for tension or negative compression), which is commonly used to determine structural safety in civil engineering. Some nodes are fixed, highlighted by dark blue dots in the graph, while the rest are free (i.e. can move.)

You may have heard of Hooke's law for springs from your physics class: F = k * Δl, where Δl is change in spring length and k is a constant related to the spring. Members are also like springs. In real civil structures the deformation is small, we are often only interested in a linear approximation.

How the solver works -

If we write the deflection (i.e. displacement vector after deformation) of all free nodes in a vector, with linear approximation, a large square matrix can be used to map the deflection vector to a vector of applied forces at each node. The matrix is commonly referred as the stiffness matrix. Typically, the stiffness matrix is symmetric, positive definite (more deformation leads to more force), and sparse (i.e. vast majority of components are zero).

Given forces in each node, we can solve the linear system to find deflection of each free node, and use Hooke's law to find forces in all members. The conjugate gradient method, an iterative method, is commonly used to approximate the solution of the linear system. It converges for positive definite matrices and runs typically fast for sparse matrices.

Implementation details -

The graph filters truss nodes by an implicit function (i.e. nodes = set of { cell coordinates (x,y,z) with f(x,y,z)<0 }). By connecting them with members of equal lengths, this creates a truss resembling my childhood magnetic stick toy.

Once the update button is clicked, it constructs the truss, and it iteratively solves for deflections using the conjugate gradient method. A line visualizes the residual in logarithmic scale, and the solver converges as the line reaches the bottom. The solving process is updated to the truss in real time.

In visualization, member tension and compression are highlighted in orange and blue, and nodes are highlighted in line of purples from dark blue to red for low to high deflection magnitudes. An animation is created to view a transition from original to deflected nodes.

Click this to update truss

It can take a while to solve - This is the case even for commercial CAD software.
However, this graph visualizes solver progress in real time, and you can still rotate the viewport with minimal lag while it's solving.

list.title:
Truss definition and domain:

You can change truss shape here.
After changing the expression, make sure to click the "trussRebuild" button to recompute.

list.text: Nodes are points with integer coordinates and trussFunc<=0
Click to update truss - Have a button here so we don't have to scroll up/down to update it

List of presets:
- Tower: in a shape of the landmark tower in Paris
- Tree: in a shape of a Christmas tree
- Pyramid: in a shape similar to the Sphinx pyramid
- Bridge: a beam bridge with two supports
- Storey: a storey supported by four pillars
- Tower Crane: a model of a construction tower crane

Tips for coming up with new shapes:
- max(|x|-rx,|y|-ry,|z|-rz) gives a cuboid
- f(x-tx,y-ty,z-tz) translates a shape
- adding/subtracting a scalar offsets a shape
- use min for union, max for intersection

Pay attention to avoid nodes where all connected members are coplanar, since this causes degeneracy, which can blow up the linear system solver. (This is less an issue with a nonlinear mass-spring model, or with stiffness in member bending.)
Enable this to visualize implicit equation
Only sample from -x[bound] to x[bound], -y[bound] to y[bound], 0 to z[bound]

list.title:
Truss generation - Node sampling

Use actions to speed up graph loading - they don't have to be re-computed on every graph load.

list.text: Number of sampling nodes per dimension

Sample nodes on a uniform grid

It samples points on a 3D axis-aligned grid, then applies a linear transformation to map them to points inside the domain

I_ug: integer indices of grid points (0 to n[sx]-1, 0 to n[sy]-1, 0 to n[sz]-1)
p_ug: points roughly aligned with the domain, with slight overflow

Then it filters points to be included as truss nodes:
v_ugf: 1 if point is inside the defined function, 0 otherwise
v_ugb: 1 if point is inside the bounded domain, 0 otherwise
v_ug: intersection of v_ugf and v_ugb, 1 if both are 1 and 0 otherwise
All nodes touch the base is made fixed

Filter node points

k_p[i] turns final index i to original index
k_pInv[i] turns original index i into final index

p_p and I_p are filtered point coordinates and 3D integer indices

Member directions:

Adding integer indices of a node by a member direction gives the (possible) integer indices of another node.

Use m_dirs0 for even z and m_dirs1 for odd z.
Give index for a point and index for a member direction, return the direction

Sample all possible members

m_has: give the integer indices of a point, return 1 if there's a node there and 0 otherwise
m_idx: store a list of members as points (i,j) where i,j are indices of two nodes, or (0,0) if the member doesn't exist

list.title: Truss generation - Matrix and vector setup

list.text:
Create a sparsity for the stiffness matrix

This is not the actual stiffness matrix - The actual stiffness matrix is implemented as a linear operator for simplicity

Partially inspired by CSR matrix: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sparse_matrix#Compressed_sparse_row_%28CSR%2C_CRS_or_Yale_format%29

A_I: pairs of indices indicating members
A_count[i] gives the number of members connected to node i
A_start[i] and A_end[i] indicates a segment of A_I that contains members connected to node i

Applied forces at each node

Each node weights w_node, each member weights w_member that is evenly distributed to both connected nodes
Clear truss

Construction

It implements it step by step, in a manner similar to a finite state machine
Number of nodes, fixed and free
Number of members

list.title:
Stiffness-vector product

Instead of storing the entire stiffness matrix, it is implemented as a linear operator for simplicity, which is sufficient for the conjugate gradient solver

list.text: direction for each member

"spring constant" for each member

It should be inversely proportional to length, although in this case all lengths are 1

Linearized displacement-to-force transform

F = k Δl in direction of Δl = k dot(Δl/|Δl|, disp) (Δl/|Δl|) = k dot(n, disp) n

where n is normalized Δl, assumed to be constant since real trusses deform little

ApCg: Linearized stiffness-vector product, for use in conjugate gradient solve

It takes a list of forces (padded by fixed nodes in front), and returns the stiffness matrix multiplied by the forces (not padded)

Check N_fixed < N to make sure it's not giving an error that breaks the graph when there's no free node. (b_cg is defined in the conjugate gradient solver section.)

Add a tiny amount of diagonal components to prevent degeneracy that "blows off" the solver.

Degeneracy occurs when the stiffness matrix is positive semi-definite instead of strictly positive definite. This happens when there are nodes with all connected members being coplanar, or the truss has no fixed nodes that makes it fall freely.

(optional, manually switch to this if solver "blows off")

list.title:
Conjugate gradient solver

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjugate_gradient_method
x_cg: linear system solution
r_cg: residuals
p_cg: search direction

Use actions to speed up graph loading - they don't have to be re-computed on every graph load.

list.text: Configurations - Reset button and residual tolerance
Initialization

list.latex: c_{gInit}=x_{cg}\to x_{cgInit},\ r_{cg}\to r_{cgInit}\left(\right),\ p_{cg}\to r_{cgInit}\left(\right),\ c_{gErrorList}\to\left[\right]

list.text:
Iteration step - 

Make this in a single step so we don't need to run multiple "clock cycles."

Cross your fingers and hope Desmos actually optimizes repeated expressions for performance.

list.latex: c_{gIter}=x_{cg}\to x_{cg}+\alpha_{cg}\left(\right)\cdot p_{cg},\ p_{cg}\to r_{cg1}\left(\right)+\frac{\operatorname{total}\left(\left|r_{cg1}\left(\right)\right|^{2}\right)}{\operatorname{total}\left(r_{cg}\cdot r_{cg}\right)}\cdot p_{cg},\ r_{cg}\to r_{cg1}\left(\right)

list.text: Looping and stopping criteria

Residual line plot - Logarithmic plot, with converged residual at the bottom.

cgErrorList stores residuals normalized by tolerance, with a value lower than 1 indicating convergence.

Use an error threshold between 0 and 1 to reduce the artifact that the final converging iteration doesn't get displayed.
Text - Hard-coded line segments represented by points and indices

list.title: Get node deflection and member forces

list.text: deflection - zero at fixed nodes, solver result at free nodes
member forces from Hooke's law, linear approximation

The visualization removes Desmos default bounding box and creates a custom box that can be rotated via slider/ticker animation.

To disable bounding box via scripting (JavaScript in browser developer console):
- Get the graph state as a JavaScript object using Calc.getState()
- For the state object, under `graph`, create or set attribute `showBox3D` with value false
- Use Calc.setState() to set the updated state object

To disable bounding box via GUI, see comments under this Reddit post: https://www.reddit.com/r/desmos/comments/1f8ihwn/is_it_possible_to_remove_the_box_in_desmos3d_its/
Animation variables
Duration of each part of animation

Time variables of each part of animation

step: height of the truss during construction
deflect: linear interpolation between original and deformed node positions
rotate: angle of rotation in radians
Function that rotates a point about z-axis based on t_rotate
Axes and grid
Clipping domain - segments of indexed points

list.latex: p_{bbox}=r_{otate}\left(\left(p_{bbox0}.x\cdot x_{bound},\ p_{bbox0}.y\cdot y_{bound},\ p_{bbox0}.z\cdot z_{bound}\cdot z_{scale}\right)\right)

Deformed truss nodes

Line of purples represent deflection magnitude

Deformed truss members

Orange is tension, blue is compression

Main update routine

Swap stepMain and stepMain1 if you are modelling the truss and would like some quick preview without expensive solving.
(you can do this by adding/deleting one digit)
linear time prefix sum by @fad
Clip a number between 0 and 1
